key_points: The second impeachment trial of former President Donald Trump raises crucial political and legal questions.
The U.S. Constitution grants Congress the sole authority to impeach and remove a president for "treason, high crimes and misdemeanors".
Trump was impeached for "incitement of insurrection" following the January 6 Capitol invasion by his political supporters.
Trump's lawyers argue his speech did not incite violence and is protected under the First Amendment.
Legal experts largely agree the Constitution permits the impeachment of a former official.
House managers argue Trump incited the crowd at the Capitol; Trump's lawyers argue for peaceful demonstration intentions.
The definition of incitement in an impeachment trial is broader than in criminal courts, allowing for a wider range of speech to be scrutinized.
The First Amendment's protection of free speech has nuanced applications in impeachment proceedings.
More than 170 constitutional law scholars believe the impeachment of a former president is constitutional.
The discussion surrounding First Amendment protections and incitement standards is key to Trump's impeachment defense.
spokespersons: Jan Baran (US Supreme Court practitioner, Holtzman Vogel Josefiak and Torchinsky)
